author: @OZtwo
text: Odd enough I'm starting here because I got a Jetson Nano (4GB B01) and a basic Jetbot and I want to learn more about AI programming in Python. My hopes are to make a robot like the Vector Robot but with a bit more brains that will be able to train itself. I was able to build a basic dumb robot version which has 0 AI but is able to sense when it stops by comparing 2 images using average pixel colors of the image which makes it very fast in processing since this really only takes up like 3 lines of code. Now that I do have my dumb robot I need to move on to the next level and try and understand AI and then of course figure out how I can train the robot so it will be able to train itself. (when it gets stuck it takes 5 images and then trains off that data which takes about 10 minutes). All that is left is to figure out how to merge the new data to the old data and again learn Python. :)  But the main reason I'm here also is that GTA would be the perfect sandbox to run tests.

author: @Ryfibi
text: In linux do this: import numpy as np import cv2 import time from mss import mss from PIL import Image  sct = mss() last_time = time.time() while 1:     w, h = 800, 450     monitor = {'top': 65, 'left': 0, 'width': w, 'height': h}     img = Image.frombytes('RGB', (w,h), sct.grab(monitor).rgb)     cv2.imshow('test', cv2.cvtColor(np.array(img), cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR))     print('Loop took {} seconds.'.format(time.time()-last_time))     last_time = time.time()     if cv2.waitKey(25) & 0xFF == ord('q'):         cv2.destroyAllWindows()         break

author: @industrialdonut7681
text: I get that this is episode one and that the rest of the series is ahead of me but, given the "two things" you checked to make sure that this project was viable from the start, with one of them being that you could run and train the AI on the game at a reasonable framerate (for it), would 1 really be that bad? For example, I was thinking about this earlier, and what if you ran the game just at 1 or even half a frame per second, but then for its output options instead of just it instantly reacting and doing something, it has then a 1 or 2 second action-queue it adds to to actually play the game. So, based on one frame, it could 'plan out' the next second of its gameplay instead of just instantly having to react on a frame by frame basis. Would that be reasonable? I think it wouldn't be too hard to implement in the python code if you've already got the method of creating actions and putting those in the game anyway.

author: @soumen_das
text: Another option one can try in Ubuntu or other os: 1) Use Udacity car simulator (https://github.com/udacity/self-driving-car-sim) 2) Use pip install mss (PIL ImageGrab is not available for linux. Hence is the only alternative in linux. Interestingly this provides 70fps or more while running Udacity car simulator. Haven't checked with GTA 5)  The code: import time import cv2 import mss import numpy as np  def screen_record):       with mss.mss() as sct:              monitor = {'top':40,'left':0,'width':800,'height':640}              while 'Screen capturing':                       last_time = time.time()                       img = np.array(sct.grab(monitor))                      cv2.imshow('OpenCV/Numpy normal', processed_img)                      print('fps:{0}''.format(1/(time.time()-last_time)))                      if cv2.waitKey(25) & 0xFF--ord('q'):                                cv2.destroyAllWindows()                                break  screen_record()

author: @brandonbahret5632
text: I've done something similar to this in the past, only like 1% the complexity. I made an Ai to play Breakout for the Atari 2600. The ai was made in C++ using the windows api to read pixel data from windows. Then I process those images to extract game states that powers decisions.   No machine learning, or complicated math used, just I only used first year high school level algebra.   https://github.com/BrandonBahret/Breakout-AI  I wish I knew about ImageGrab with PIL, that would have saved me the headache of interfacing with the Windows API to grab frames with C++.

author: @bradleyphillips5254
text: you're using bang-bang control, maybe use proportional or PID, you'd either want to set the duration of the key press or number of key presses proportional to the gradient.  might be worth using multiprocessing to put all of the control logic on a different core. could also try taking the frame, convert to gray, serialize and fire off to a pool, so road boundary, blob rate of size growth calculation etc can run in parallel.  to tune your PID controller, you'd want to find a straight stretch of road, and find the maximum stable proportional gain, (oscillating but stable), then the frequency of oscillation can be used to derive rough PID parameters using the Zeigler Nichols equations.  using PID will improve control 10x at least.  for speed determinations, maybe identify blobs outside of the lines and calculate rate of growth? it'll be rough but maybe enough.   once you have a rough idea of speed, you can tune your controller at a range of speeds, then use interpolation for "gain scheduling" so your controller pid parameters are always optimal.  if you want to get more fancy, you could use "direct synthesis" to calculate controller parameters based on an ideal "reference trajectory". you could even take it further and make your model adaptive so it improves over time.  fuzzy control might be an option too...  I'm a huge fan of your videos and this is a fantastic project, I kind of want to write my own version of this.  you might get more finesse with a simulated joy stick, also I've ported my Python open CV to cpp and it runs much faster

author: @patrickbreach5094
text: I think the performance was bad initially because a copy was being made in converting the image to a numpy array maybe because of the dtype being passed. I would try using `np.asarray` instead and play with the dtype to get a bit better than 10fps. Also, why not resample the PIL image before converting to a numpy array?
